comments.body: How about using https://github.com/frenic/csstype for css values?

Oh interesting, I didn‚Äôt know you could reference external dependencies. Great! üëå 

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/fe3fcd77c952fdc23670f0a1c66431384c10862c/types/react/package.json#L4
Awesome suggestion! I'll dig into it.

@maxdeviant @phobon FYI You are listed as maintainers here because you‚Äôve done work on these types, but it does mean that the DT bot will ping you and ask for a review anytime a PR for this file is made. Please let us know if you‚Äôd like to be removed, for now we‚Äôll assume you want to be listed.
Yeah, I'm absolutely happy with this, thanks for kicking this all off üëç

Grid auto flow is actually a union type, so you could write it like:

```
export type GridAutoFlowValue =
    "row"
    | "column"
    | "dense"
    | "row dense"
    | "column dense"
    | "inherit"
    | "initial"
    | "unset";
```
@zephraph we should start using that CSS styles dependency that was mentioned on the first PR asap to set a precedent for people to follow.
With the change to GridAutoFlowValue above, this can stay as is - a string
This can be a ``` string | number``` right?
Are you aware that this means signing up as a maintainer and that you‚Äôll get pinged on future PRs and tickets (once the bot starts working again, that is)?
Yep aware, but thanks for noticing it :)
Just want to check if the implication of adding to this header is clear? I.e. you‚Äôre signing up as a maintainer of the types and will get pinged for each new issue/PR for these types.
Yes thanks, I'd like to help maintain these types
Ace üôè
Just so you know, by putting your name here you're signing up for receiving and maintaining these types as in future PR's and issues you will be tagged for help in resolving or reviewing.
What's the advantage to changing all of these? This change throughout the file makes it hard to see where other, actual functionality changes are made.
It might make it a little less clear in terms of specific PR additions but it _is_ a good change in terms of DRYness.

These changes are not just stylistic they are related to:
- Add propTypes to Style Functions as per the implementation

You‚Äôll find the related tests at the bottom of the tests file. 

I couldn‚Äôt find a better way to declare those functions with TS but if you have a better solution I‚Äôll happily amend this PR.

I don't have an issue with the change! More that this amount of code-style changes skews the view into the actual functional changes you've implemented. This is just my personal opinion- I like to keep code cleanup PRs separate from anything else just for this reason. But that's just me!
Sure, but these are not just code style changes. They change the functionality.
tbh I didn't think accounting for prop-types was necessary bc it's redundant.

It‚Äôs not. I‚Äôm using it.

[Here's a demo](https://codesandbox.io/s/q4p65j924), very simplified. 

Essentially you have a `Header` component, which renders a primitive, in this case a `Flex`. You want the `Header` to take all the system props that `Flex` accepts (`space`) and exclude other props that are not related to that. `Header` also takes a menu click callback. 

Using `space.propTpyes` is a decent way of doing this.
cc @jxnblk, thoughts on this change? I think it more closely captures `styled-system`'s behavior...
Glad to help out! It's been bothering me as well. üòÑ I don't have any problem with the changes you're suggesting. I can update this PR as soon as I have a few extra minutes
But this is a change in the library as well right? Or just the typings?
No just the typings. Scale has been available as a 2nd arg since 4.0.
@peduarte relevant changelog; https://github.com/styled-system/styled-system/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#v400-2019-02-23

Ahhh yes makes sense üëç 

We should totally add typings to scale too
Not sure if this matters for the change here but scales can include nested objects or arrays, not just numbers and strings
Do those ‚Äúnested objects‚Äù not follow a particular shape?
Scales aren't known upfront, so should be generic below too actually. (we use deeply nested objects for example).
Rev up the version to 5.1 at the top of the file.
